For Release Wed PMs, Dec 27 and Thereafter
Book on Swiss Army Hits Best-Seller Lists
DOC.TEXT: It doesn't compare with his ``Stiller'' or other works that won worldwide attention. But at 78, novelist-playwright Max Frisch has broken eight years of literary silence and has returned to Swiss best-seller lists. The subject of his new book is Switzerland's militia army, which has not fought a foreign war in five centuries. The army has fascinated him since he boarded a train on Sept. 1, 1939 to join an artillery unit based in the Alps. At that time he was convinced he would help defend the neutral country against an invasion by the Nazis. His concern focused on a German Jewish resident of Basel, who was then his girlfriend. Two of his books, published in 1940 and 1974, deal with his wartime experience, marking his conversion to increasingly radical pacificism. The third was jotted down in barely two months last spring. It was timed to add fuel to a nationwide debate on a recent proposal that sought the abolition of the 625,000-man Swiss army. Frisch's new ``Switzerland Without an Army?'' features a sparsely worded dialogue between a ``grandfather,'' easily identifiable as the author himself, and his ``grandson,'' Jonas. Subtitled ``A Palaver,'' it is actually a collection of pros and cons in the debate, though Frisch makes no secret of his opinion. ``We need the army, seriously,'' the grandfather at one point tells a doubting Jonas, who is thinking of possibly emigrating to the United States. The grandfather lists the well-worn whys _ ``school of life, school of men, school of the nation'' _ before adding what to him is the principal reason, ``the bodyguard of the reign of the wealthy.'' Once more, Frisch shows himself as a disillusioned critic of the Swiss system. ``Their misery is the purchasing power without any great hope,'' the grandfather says of his compatriots. ``They spend their vacations in the service of economic growth.'' The army is not ``our army,'' Jonas is told, but an ``army that is maneuvering on our territory as the army of the Swiss society of finance and officers.'' The book went into its fifth edition three months after publication, and has been translated into four languages. A dramatized version, ``Jonas and His Veteran,'' premiered at Zurich's prestigious Schauspielhaus theater Oct. 20, directed by Benno Besson, a Swiss disciple of Bertolt Brecht. A French language version went on stage one day later at Lausanne. The performances drew rounds of applause, but reviewers were mixed. ``It is a convincing text,'' said the Zurich weekly Sonntagszeitung, praising Frisch's ``subtle argumentation, (and) his stylistic elegance.'' The reasons presented are of such ``cogent logic that the question ought to be on the mind of everyone leaving the theater: How could one ever believe in the institution of the army?'' For the Berner Zeitung of Bern, the play showed that the idea of a Switzerland without an army can be the subject of a ``spirited discussion.'' Another Bern newspaper, Der Bund, said the play ``lacked the stylistic power, the poetic weight and dramaturgic logic of `Triptych,''' the last work Frisch wrote exclusively for the stage in 1978. Frisch's ``grandfather'' is sure the Swiss army is sure to stay. ``If the Swiss army is ever be disbanded, it will not be by a referendum but by a war.''
